data.text: What Sort of Bikes Suitable for Road Touring in Europe
Hey what sort of bikes are most suitable for long distance road touring around Europe ? Most of the photos of bikes on here are so loaded up with kit i can't tell !

Whatever you can get hold of. I ride an old mtb, converted to take racks, on 26" wheels, and it's great, but I have friends on expensive custom built touring bikes, on 700c's, with drop bars......but everything works, you are the key component :-)
data.author: Robin Batute

data.text: Just to clarify, in order to fit racks I had to do a bit of work and I initially fabricated brackets that the axles went through, but I have now found other options, racks, both front and rear, that fit directly to the axles, and attach to the bike with clamps and brackets that are supplied with the racks. This summer I rode 6500kms to Uzbekistan, with about 60kg of luggage, on my 30 year old mtb, and nothing bad happened. Proof, if it were needed, that pretty much any bike will do the job :-)
data.author: Robin Batute

data.text: why almost 10st of gear ,OK the bags could be 6kg? But that's still 9st of gear. Was it a lead lined tent??
data.author: GaryGary Sheridan

data.text: I was basically moving house, so although I left some of my stuff with friends to send on to me, I had to take quite a lot with me. It wasn't ideal, but it did prove how much I could carry and still make good progress :-)
data.author: Robin Batute

data.text: similar methinks.
data.author: GaryGary Sheridan

data.text: hahaha it wasn't that bad :-)
data.author: Robin Batute

data.text: That is what a am looking for... any links or further information about that would be apreciated...
data.author: Ata Oru

data.text: OK so my front rack is a Minoura, and my rear was an Axiom Journey, but I wouldn't recommend the Axiom, instead I would suggest a Tubus with a universal fitting kit.
data.author: Robin Batute

data.text: I think the Minoura is an mt4000, or something like that....
data.author: Robin Batute

data.text: before I had these 2 racks I had a Blackburn grid 1 on the back, mounted to a homemade bracket that was connected to the bike through the rear axle, and the mudguard hole.
data.author: Robin Batute

data.text: I can't remember what I had on the front, but the Minoura is bombproof, if you can find one I highly recommend them.
data.author: Robin Batute

data.text: I'm going to ask you to look up Specialized Crossroad from the 90s. Steel Chromoly frame with amazing tire clearance. It's cheap as fuck too.
data.author: Bogdan C. Cojocaru

data.text: Any bike will do so long as it is mechanically sound.
data.author: Philip Lenaghan

data.text: Im in general agreement- far too much attention to the right brands etc - but a key point is it has rack mountings, AND sufficient wheelbase that it can carry panniers on the rear (assuming that is what you intend) without your heels hitting them on each pedal-revolution. Hence, some 'sports'/triathlon type bikes with short-wheelbase aren't appropriate.
data.author: Richard Frankel

data.text: I ride a Planet X London Road, with 700 by 32 tyres 👍🏻
data.author: Neil Fife Fiford

data.text: I ride a TREK 520 Disc. Surly Long Haul Trucker is another good option as is a Fuji Touring Disc ...and there are many, many more good ones. My preference would be a steel-frame bike as they ride more comfortably than aluminium bikes (in my opinion, having had both) and the hold up better against the rigours of the road. For road touring I would always go for 28" wheels for speed. I would also go for 38-42mm wide tires due to the added comfort. There are many good (and fast) options in that size space to choose from. Now this is just my expirience, other people may see it differently based on their expiriences. To each his own, of course, but these would be my reccomendations.
data.author: Þórður Ólafur Þórðarson

data.text: What is the noticable difference when riding Aluminium V bike?
data.author: David O'Donnell

data.text: - My experience was that the alu frame was stiffer, while the steel frame has a degree of flex to it that works like a cushioning/supension of sorts and adds to the comfort level. It is really noticable, to be honest.
data.author: Þórður Ólafur Þórðarson

data.text: For long distance => long term => many different scenarios to be in => well prepared with all the goodies to make the experience enjoyable. Don`t be scared from bulk and weight, very low gear takes care of that with easy, its no a race but a ride to enjoy the details. If you are in tight budget, a 26" quality MTB will be fantastic (27 speed is the sweet spot, 36T the biggest cog in the sprocket and 22T the smallest chairing.) Those are made to jump around and catch abuse. For best results set marathon mondial tires.
data.author: Jo Touring

data.text: Lapierre crosshill has loads of mounting points for racks and bags etc it was made for bike packing.
data.author: Marc Boylen

data.text: I didn't know anything then I started out. I went for it with a hybrid bike and then bought an old dawes sardar 2 tandem for £300 from ebay. Both worked really well. The secret is to ride another, close to home with full loads. Borrow friends bikes if you can, try lots of different things and see what works. I saw someone with a delivery bike once.
data.author: David Botterill

data.text: I ride a Raliegh 27 speed fat bike. And I go so light my bike shows up through the kit. Any bike will do, as long as it's well built to hold up to the multitude of mi/km.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: anything BUT a road bike that is.
data.author: Geoffrey Silverstein

data.text: Been my road bike for 3 years and 20,000 miles touring. Last actual road bike I had was in 1983-84 when I rode a Schwinn 7000 miles around the USA on my second bike tour. Since then I've ridden mountain bikes, till I got this fatty 3 years ago.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: I have a carbon road bike and it is crap, nowhere to hang or mount stuff
data.author: Peter Evans

data.text: check out Tailfin racks. They’re carbon and fit cabin bikes. I’m using one now:
data.author: Douglas Concha

data.text: with yours being a 27 speed can you keep up with an average mountain bike? I haven't owned a fat hike, I've only tried riding a couple and they only had 1 gear on front and I couldn't get them moving any quicker then a 1 speed cruiser, well close to that speed anyway. I actually saw a guy moving on one today though so I'm wondering if 1 like yours with 3 on the front will go quicker, or if he changed the gearing on his. I didn't have a chance to ask as he was going quick the other way before I realized what he was on.
data.author: Joe Fowler

data.text: There is always someone faster than me. If you can spin in a high gear, you will go faster than spinning in a middle gear. I see guys tearing past me on the flat, on MTBs, but they will be in a high gear and spinning. I recon they are building to that speed over maybe half a mile. Geared for touring is not geared for speed, but geared for carrying a load at a pace you can ride all day, if needs be, and geared to pull a load up hills. Changing the gear set up can prove both expensive and fruitless.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I suppose it can keep up with a mountain biker. But I like the gearing more for climbing hills on tour more. My next tour though I'm doing on a gravel bike which has 24 gears. Riding first to Tucson then around Southern Arizona till spring. After that hasn't been decided yet.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: it does not have to be expensive. Take the setup of a mountain bike. My KHS 24 speed hybrid is geared to qo quick, my Jamis Durango 27 does it all. I can tow heavy and I live in mountains, or I can really get moving on it. It has the widest range for gearing I've ever tried. I'm thinking I would need to build up a lot more muscle though to keep moving with that gearing on 4.5 inch tires
data.author: Joe Fowler

data.text: why not a road bike with wider tires? I have an old Fuji S-12-S with Jones bar and new SRAM drivetrain, front and rear Ortliebs, rim brakes. It’s a bit tall compared to the newer ones with longer seat posts and stems, but it suits me for a touring bike. I’d like to know why lots of folx think fat tire bikes are better for all touring. Obviously they’re great for off road, but I am fine on my Fuji even on some gravel. I use 2” tires. Please comment.
data.author: Edwin Booth

data.text: I've been touring on my fat bike 3 years, 8 months a year. My tires are called Big Smoothies with a 1 inch wide road tread and knobbies on the edges. Yes, that can be slower, but I tour to see the countryside not zip through them. And I have a 3x9 27 gear set up that climbs almost any road grade with ease. I've been touring 40 years Sept to May on road, mountain and now my fatty. I think the fat bike is the best bike I've ridden.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: rim brakes aren’t strong enough to stop a fully loaded touring bike. It’s too heavy.
data.author: Geoffrey Silverstein

data.text: my brakes a are disc
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: Depends on what your carrying. I toured on bike with rim brakes from 1982 to 2019. I only carry 22 lbs of gear plus food and water for a few days at a time. Rim brakes were all that existed on bikes till about 25 years ago.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: properly adjusted rim brakes (and tuned rims) work just fine on a fully loaded touring bike. The issue is really what happens when a spoke breaks and the rim becomes untrue. Then I would agree with you entirely. But sure, disks are better overall.
data.author: Edwin Booth

data.text: what rear rack are you using? The bags look to be proprietary to the rack. Probably quite expensive, too.
data.author: Edwin Booth

data.text: Topeak Super Tourist Fat Disc. The bag on top is a Topeak MTX Trunk bag DXP and the panniers are Burley 22L.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: Do a web search for touring bikes. There’s a reason they are called touring bikes because thy are purposed made. Some are already mentioned in this thread.
data.author: Ali Albayrak

data.text: I have a Genesis Tour de Fer 10, hasn't let me down yet after many km's 🤞 it will keep going for many more!
data.author: Tom Pacheco

data.text: I’m cycling Europe on a steel, single-speed bicycle. Love it! 🚲 charity: bicycle
data.author: Douglas Concha

data.text: I would say any bike that suits your body parameters. Size does matter. But Touring bikes really help in long distances with load.
data.author: Sunil Kolambkar

data.author: Piotr Woszczenko

data.text: For europa would steer clear from any drop bar road bikes some 650b tyres and wide ones at that only holland has nice bike lanes and surfaces france spain belgium etc full of potholes and rocked up roads
data.author: Menno Pieters
Dave Prestidge

data.text: I ride a Fuji touring LTD, but the frame broke around the attachment points for the rear rack after less than 10.000 km. got a new frame with the warranty though. My dream frame is a surly long haul trucker, but it has been discontinued. That being said, I’d recommend doing some test tours on your current bike if you have one and see if it works for you before spending a lot of money. Obviously it wouldn’t be appropriate to climb the Swiss alps if you own a single speed bicycle, but maybe you have something suitable. I bought my Fuji before my first tour because I figured that my 7 speed city bike wouldn’t do 😄
data.author: Søren Rosenius Olsen

data.text: Was it an aluminium frame which broke?
data.author: Roman Mentor

data.text: Fuji touring LTD is made of steel.
data.author: Søren Rosenius Olsen
